prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for asking my bulimic roommate to control herself?
I (F20) have been living with my roommate (F20) for about a year now. We’ve already made plans to move out and live with other people in a few months (unrelated to any of this). For the most part, she’s a really good roommate; she pays everything on time, cleans the whole apartment, is very quiet, and even though we aren’t friends per se we are friendly and get along pretty well.


She doesn’t really cook, and her side of the fridge/her cupboards are pretty much bare (like she literally just has condiments in the fridge right now). I enjoy cooking and am on a bit of a budget (I support myself) so I cook 3 meals a day, 7 days a week (since I can’t afford to eat out). 


Starting when we first moved in, I started noticing things were off with my food. Not that things were missing (although sometimes I would have less of something than I thought) but also that I would sometimes have more, of a different product than I remember buying (ie going to eat some crackers and them being kinda whole grain-y despite the box saying original). I didn’t really think much of it, or just assumed I was being absent minded.


Lately though, it’s been getting much worse and it’s clear she’s taking my food and trying to replace it (hence the products sometimes being slightly different). I’ve gone into the cupboards and found unopened packages of things that I KNOW I’ve already opened.


Last week I confronted her about this and she broke down crying and told me she’s been bulimic for a wrong time, she knows it’s wrong, but she can’t help binging on my food sometimes, blah blah. Also that she doesn’t want to be like this but she’s stuck on a waitlist for treatment. She was very upset and apologetic but I was still mad at her. I told her that I’m sorry she has that issue but it shouldn’t be my problem and if she needs to eat she can just buy her own food since her parents support her. She pointed out that she replaces everything she takes but it still bothers me knowing that someone is eating MY food. I understand there’s something wrong with her but it’s not like she can’t control herself at the grocery store and eats right off the shelves, or at restaurants takes from other people’s tables. I told her that and I don’t understand why this is any different; it’s not socially acceptable to take other people’s property regardless of what’s wrong with you. 


She cried in her room for a long time and we haven’t spoken or made eye contact since then, although I’m trying to be nice. I feel bad but I also don’t think I actually did anything wrong. We’re both 20, IMO it’s not unreasonable to expect her to control herself. Like do I want to eat a whole box of cookies? Sure, but I don’t because I know better. I’m just asking her to exercise the same restraint here. 


Am I the asshole?

"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's tackle this. So the user is asking whether the author (the person who posted the story) is in the wrong for confronting their bulimic roommate about taking their food.

First, I need to understand the situation. The roommate has bulimia and has been taking the author's food without asking, even replacing it sometimes. The author confronted her, she cried, and now there's tension. The author is questioning if they were right to do so.

The key points here are: the roommate has a mental health issue, the author is on a budget and cooking for themselves, the roommate is taking food and trying to replace it, and the author confronted her. The author's argument is that regardless of the roommate's condition, taking someone else's food isn't acceptable. The roommate's side is that she's struggling with an eating disorder and is in treatment but on a waitlist.

Now, to determine if the author is in the wrong. On one hand, the author has a right to their belongings, including food. It's not okay to take things without permission, even with a mental health condition. The author's frustration is understandable, especially since they're managing a budget and cooking daily. They had a right to address the issue directly, especially after noticing ongoing behavior.

On the other hand, the roommate is dealing with a serious eating disorder, which is a health issue. The author's response was firm and public, leading to the roommate breaking down. The confrontation might have been harsh, but the author's intent was to set boundaries. The roommate's actions are a result of her illness, which isn't her fault, but the author is also within their rights to ask for their space and belongings to be respected.

The author didn't accuse her of something they didn't do; they observed the behavior and confronted her. The roommate admitted her issue, so the author's response was based on the truth. The author also suggested that the roommate can buy her own food, which is a reasonable solution. The author's main point is about mutual respect and boundaries in a shared living space.

Mental health issues don't excuse taking others' property, but they do require empathy. The author showed some empathy by trying to be nice afterward but stood their ground. The roommate's responsibility is to seek treatment and manage her condition, which she's attempting. The author's actions were about self-respect and setting clear boundaries, which are important in any living situation.

So, considering both sides, the author isn't in the wrong for standing up for their belongings and setting boundaries, even though the roommate has a health issue. The roommate needs to take responsibility for her actions, and the author is justified in asking her to do so.
